children.text: This is a challenging and rewarding day of high-altitude trekking. The route follows an old Roman road past the beautiful church of Notre-Dame de la Gorge. A steep climb leads to the Col du Bonhomme and then onwards to the Croix du Bonhomme, where a refuge provides a welcome stop. The landscape becomes wilder and more remote as the trail descends into the secluded valley of Les Chapieux, a small hamlet with limited amenities.

accommodations.name: Refuge de la Croix du Bonhomme

children.text: The journey begins in the Chamonix valley at Les Houches. This initial stage serves as a good warm-up for the days ahead. The trail ascends via the Col de Voza, offering the first stunning panoramas of the Mont Blanc range. Trekkers can opt to take the Bellevue cable car to ease into the trek. The path then descends through forests and meadows, passing the impressive Bionnassay glacier and its suspension bridge, before arriving in the picturesque village of Les Contamines-Montjoie.

Leaving France, this stage crosses into Italy over the Col de la Seigne. The ascent offers dramatic views back into the Vallée des Glaciers and opens up to a spectacular panorama of the Italian side of the Mont Blanc massif, including the Aiguille Noire de Peuterey and the Brenva Glacier. The descent leads to the Val Veni and the historic Rifugio Elisabetta Soldini, perched impressively at the foot of the Glacier de la Lée Blanche.

This stage offers a more leisurely day with a significant amount of descent. The trail follows the beautiful and relatively flat Val Veni, with constant, stunning views of Mont Blanc. The path passes by the vibrant blue Lac Combal before a final ascent to the ski area of Col Chécrouit. From here, a long and steep descent leads to the charming and bustling Italian alpine town of Courmayeur, known for its excellent food and vibrant atmosphere.

After a steep climb out of Courmayeur to the Refuge Bertone, this stage becomes a spectacular balcony walk with some of the most iconic views of the entire TMB. The trail contours high above the Italian Val Ferret, offering uninterrupted panoramas of the Grandes Jorasses and the dramatic southern face of the Mont Blanc massif. The day concludes at the renowned Rifugio Bonatti, named after the famous Italian mountaineer Walter Bonatti.

This long stage involves crossing the Grand Col Ferret, which marks the border between Italy and Switzerland. The ascent to the col is gradual and offers incredible retrospective views of the Italian Val Ferret. From the pass, the landscape transforms into the gentler, pastoral scenery of the Swiss Val Ferret. A long and steady descent through alpine meadows and past traditional Swiss farms leads to the peaceful village of La Fouly.

Considered one of the easiest stages of the TMB, this day offers a pleasant and mostly flat walk through the picturesque Swiss Val Ferret. The trail meanders alongside the Dranse de Ferret river, passing through charming hamlets with traditional wooden chalets. The final section involves a gentle climb through the forest to the idyllic lakeside town of Champex-Lac, a perfect spot to rest and recuperate.

This stage presents two main options: the classic route via the Col de la Forclaz or the more challenging and scenic variant over the Fenêtre d'Arpette. The classic route is a steady climb through forests to the Alp Bovine, a high pasture with a working farm and café, offering great views over the Rhône Valley. The descent leads to the Col de la Forclaz and then down to the small Swiss village of Trient, recognizable by its pink church.

Returning to France, this stage involves a significant climb to the Col de Balme. From the col, a stunning panoramic view of the Chamonix Valley, Mont Blanc, and the Aiguilles Rouges unfolds. The route then continues along the ridgeline to the Aiguillette des Posettes for even more spectacular 360-degree views before a steep descent to the hamlet of Tré-le-Champ.

This is a shorter but challenging stage renowned for its dramatic scenery and exposed sections. The trail ascends through the Aiguilles Rouges Nature Reserve, involving some sections with ladders and metal handrails. The highlight of the day is the optional but highly recommended detour to the stunning Lac Blanc, a crystal-clear mountain lake that perfectly mirrors the Mont Blanc massif. The stage ends at the La Flégère cable car station and refuge.

The final stage of the TMB is a grand finale with some of the best views of the entire trek. From La Flégère, the trail traverses on a high balcony path to Planpraz, with constant, breathtaking views of the Mont Blanc range. For a truly unforgettable experience, many hikers take the cable car up to Le Brévent, which offers an unparalleled 360-degree panorama. The trek concludes with a long and very steep descent back to the starting point in Les Houches, completing the epic circuit.
